thread.title: Jack Hale 100m world youth championship |
thread.title_full: Jack Hale 100m world youth championship | The Advertiser

author: SIMEON THOMAS-WILSON
title: Jack Hale 100m world youth championship |
text:
TASMANIA’S Jack Hale has failed to advance to the final of the 100 metres at the World Youth Championships in Colombia.
The 17-year-old, who is Australia’s fastest ever boy, had to finish in the top two of his semi-final to advance to the final held at noon on Thursday, but could only manage a sixth place in a time of 10.70 seconds.
“Just not my day, I’ve still got the 200m to come” @JackHale98 post race.
— Athletics Australia (@AthsAust) July 15, 2015
Japan’s Abdul Hakim Sani Brown equalled his championship record, winning the race in 10.30 seconds followed by Britain’s Oliver Bromby.
Hale said he would now focus on the 200 metres.
“Just not my day, I’ve still got the 200m to come,” he said post race.
Fellow Australian sprinter Jordan Shelley of NSW also missed out on a place in the final, finishing seventh in semi-final three in a time of 10.83 seconds.
Meanwhile national under-18 discus champion Samantha Peace from NSW produced a personal best of 50.59m to claim bronze and Australia’s only medal on day one.
Originally published as Jack Hale misses final at World Championships
